title: Can the Keen engine be "open-sourced"?
content:
This morning I was thinking about the Keen: "Goodbye Galaxy!" engine. After reading a brief story of Bio Menace's development, it seems that the Id Software guys were thinking on using the Keen engine for other non-Id games then.

So they licensed the engine to Apogee Software for Bio Menace. At least that's what I understood from the text file that comes with the freeware distribution of Bio Menace.

These days I think it's *impossible* to make money with that game engine. If I remember correctly, Id Software and Apogee no longer distribute/register the original (registered versions) Keen: Galaxy games. Correct me if I'm wrong. If I'm right, would it be possible to open-source the Keen: Galaxy engine like the Quake engine?

Note that I'm referring to the Keen *engine*, not the artwork or data files. Only the program, like Duke Nukem 3D or ROTT by Apogee.
[hr]
"Eat your veggies!"

title: Re: Can the Keen engine be "open-sourced"?
content: It's entirely possible, but good luck persuading them.  Although there was some talk of John Romero releasing the Keen source a while back...

title: Re:  Re: Can the Keen engine be "open-sourced"?
content:
Maybe this is obvious by now, but just in case:
Releasing source code and making a game freeware are not really related at all.
Usually in the beginning neither is the case.

If a game is then made freeware, it's still illegal to make new games with the source code the game uses.
It's only that one games, the engine (source code) might still be sold and/or used to make more games with.
Bio Menace is an example here.

If the source code is released, it's still illegal to distribute the game (except for official resellers of course), even if it hasn't been sold for 20 years (although eventually copyright becomes void, but I'd have to look up after how many years exactly).
There might still be games that use this engine that are sold.
Doom is an example here.
That's why in the case of Doom you still need the WAD-file with all the maps, textures, sprites, sounds, music, etc. in it to play a Doom port (although there is "FreeDoom", which uses home-made all-of-the-above so you can play).

I don't think I can recall an instance where both are true.
Maybe ZZT?
Usually this happens with smaller games, smaller independant developers.

I'm still hoping either John did in fact find the Commander Keen source code like mentioned in the other thread, but I still doubt it as much as when it was first mentioned, which is very much so.
It's just the no-new-information-thing, no-updates-thing, and nothing-about-it-from-John thing that make me doubt it.Retodon8
